image.altText: A group of people waving flags

props.synopsis: Beijing despises the winner of Taiwan's election, Lai Ching-tei, calling him a separatist and a troublemaker. But it can't ignore the message voters are sending with his victory, writes Kathleen Calderwood.

title.children: Taiwan just had an election. The outcome sends a big message to China

image.altText: Patients being treated at the Royal Melbourne Hospital road trauma unit.

props.synopsis: Last year was the deadliest on Australia's roads in five years, but there's no national record of how many people were left injured.

title.children: Kate works at one of Australia's busiest hospitals. Road injuries represent a 'huge chunk' of its cases

image.altText: Posing for a photo on a tree-lined dirt track, two men press their hands against the belly of a pregnant woman who is smiling

props.synopsis: The Pope's recent pronouncement against surrogacy has sparked heated global debate about the controversial issue. In Australia, surrogacy is complex: deplored by some but embraced by others whose lives have been transformed by remarkable acts of generosity and love.

title.children: Anna, Matt and Brendan's surrogacy journey blossomed into a lifelong celebration. For other surrogates, everything went wrong

image.altText: A YOUNG PERSON SITTING DRAWING AT A DESK

props.synopsis: Lilla Pearl Coffey says high school graduates of 2023 "can't afford" to find themselves at university.

title.children: High school graduates of 2023 delay university enrolment saying they 'can't afford to make mistakes' in what they study

image.altText: Left to right: Ben Shelton, Jannik Sinner, Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz and Sebastian Korda.

props.synopsis: Father time comes for everyone. Except it seems for Novak Djokovic but even the Serbian great can't stave off generation after generation forever and now could be their time to do the seemingly impossible.

title.children: Novak Djokovic is tennis's alpha male but he is being hunted by a generation who don't fear him

image.altText: Rod Laver Arena bathed in sunshine with packed stands

props.synopsis: The day has arrived — the world's best tennis players will begin to compete for the coveted Australian Open 2024 silverware. Here's your comprehensive pocket guide on the first grand slam of the season.

title.children: Want to catch all the action from the Australian Open? Here's where to watch and all the Aussie players in main draw

image.altText: A young girl serving a tennis ball

props.synopsis: In just a few years, blind and low-vision tennis has become Australia's fastest-growing blind sport, with Australians now dominating the world stage.

title.children: Kala has fallen in love with blind tennis, and she's not the only one

image.altText: Two men walk through grasslands on a sunny day

props.synopsis: It's a popular spot with bird-watchers and walkers in Canberra now. But once upon a time these grasslands were used as a military firing range

title.children: These quiet grasslands have been hiding unexploded ammunition for decades. Now it's all been dug up

image.altText: A Palestinian woman walks near the rubble of a house destroyed in an Israeli strike.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of Palestinian Australians are waiting for family members with approved visas to get a green light from border officials to leave Gaza.

title.children: Israa's family have been granted visas to Australia, but she worries every day if they will make it out of Gaza alive

image.altText: A couple in evening wear

props.synopsis: When Crown Prince Frederik and his Australian-born wife Princess Mary ascend the throne overnight, it will be a simple, pared-back affair. But it's all part of a centuries-long effort to keep the Danish monarchy going.

title.children: The key to the Danish monarchy's survival is 'informality'. Here's how Mary became their secret weapon

image.altText: Scott and Vicki hold coffee cups in a kitchen. They are smiling for the camera.

props.synopsis: This week's Iowa caucuses signal the start of the primary race for the 2024 US election. Donald Trump's the strongest polling Republican, but many caucus-goers say there are better options.

title.children: 'So many Trump haters': As a small state holds America's first big vote, some Republicans are turning

image.altText: People on the sand and water with life savers under an umbrella on Mackenzies Bay beach

props.synopsis: The mysterious appearance and disappearance of sand at a bay in Sydney's east has caused both intrigue and headaches for decades, depending on who you are.

title.children: 'Not for the faint-hearted': People told to stay away from mysterious Sydney beach

image.altText: water over double-lane highway

props.synopsis: Authorities remind the public constantly that floodwaters and cars don't mix, but drivers continue to take the risk. Here's what experts say about why people do it.

title.children: After more than 50 swift-water rescues in Victoria this week, why do people keep driving into floods?

image.altText: Firefighters with hoses near a line of smouldering trees.

props.synopsis: Two bushfire emergency warnings are issued for parts of the Shire of Chittering north-east of Perth, with lives and homes under threat.

title.children: Lives, homes under threat from two bushfires burning in the Shire of Chittering north-east of Perth

image.altText: Protesters burning flags.

props.synopsis: Yemen's Houthi rebels vow fierce retaliation for US and British strikes against them, further raising the prospect of a wider conflict in a region already beset by Israel's war in Gaza.

title.children: US launches another attack on Houthi rebels, Biden warns of further strikes

image.altText: Maldivian resort

props.synopsis: The Maldives stands to lose hundreds of millions of dollars as its giant neighbour threatens to halt its tourism there. But why is the world's most populous country flexing its muscles in that way, and what's China got to do with it?

title.children: Why is India turning the screws on a tiny island neighbour?

image.altText: A family of four standing outside their electric 4WD and camper

props.synopsis: "Green power couple" Tim and Renae McLennan want to be one of the first to travel around Australia using an electric vehicle to tow a pop-up caravan.

title.children: 'Green nomad' family plan to be the first to use an EV to tow a full-size caravan around Australia

image.altText: Rescuers at a landslide location in Columbia.

props.synopsis: A mudslide brought on by heavy rains hits a busy highway in north-west Colombia, killing dozens of people and injuring dozens more on.

title.children: Landslide in north-west Colombia kills dozens of people

image.altText: Harry Souttar celebrates with his teammates

props.synopsis: Graham Arnold's Socceroos have got their Asian Cup tilt off on the right foot, defeating India 2-0 in their opening group game in Qatar.

title.children: Socceroos defeat India 2-0 in first Asian Cup group game

image.altText: The side of a plane that has a fuselage plug area covered by plastic.

props.synopsis: The Federal Aviation Administration said the continued grounding of the planes was for the safety of American travellers.

title.children: US regulator grounds all Boeing 737 MAX 9 airplanes indefinitely, as inspections of each aircraft continue

image.altText: workers close off rozelle parklands after bonded asbestos was found in the organic mulch layed down in the playgorund

props.synopsis: The list of contaminated sites related to the Rozelle Interchange Project grows as three landscaped garden beds test positive for bonded asbestos.

title.children: Three additional sites near Sydney's Rozelle Parklands shut after more asbestos found

image.altText: African elephants entwine their trunks

props.synopsis: While the images we see in nature documentaries are filmed on location, many of the animal sounds are recorded and added later. Here's how they're made, writes Damien Pollard.

title.children: Animal sounds are rarely recorded live in documentaries. Humans make and add them in later — here's how

image.altText: Police tape in front of a crime scene set up along a suburban street.

props.synopsis: Homicide Squad detectives are investigating after a man was located in Doncaster in Melbourne's north-east.

title.children: Police investigate death of man following alleged home invasion in Melbourne's north-east

image.altText: Penny Wong covers a microphone while speaking to a government official

props.synopsis: Foreign Minister Penny Wong is one of the nation's most disciplined politicians, who heavily calculates everything she says. It's a skill she'll need as she faces her biggest challenge to date when she touches down in the Middle East.

title.children: Penny Wong never misses a microphone. She'll need that skill as she navigates the Middle East

image.altText: A snake dangles from an ice dispenser on a fridge door.

props.synopsis: When she went to turn off the radio in her outdoor entertainment area, Adelaide Hills resident Gail Auricht thought the hissing sound she could hear was an air compressor — then she spotted a red-bellied black snake caught in her fridge.

title.children: 'Enough to send a chill down anyone's spine': Snake found dangling down from ice dispenser on fridge door

image.altText: Close up of the front of an Adelaide train at the platform

props.synopsis: A 21-year-old man will appear in the Christies Beach Magistrates court on Monday charged over an alleged sexual assault on a train in Adelaide this week.

title.children: Man charged with rape over alleged sexual assault on Adelaide train

image.altText: Toilets backed up with toilet paper, and discoloured water.

props.synopsis: Raw sewage is overflowing from toilets and flooding bathrooms in some Lithgow homes during heavy rain, but the council says a long-term solution could cost around $70 million.

title.children: Residents sick of 'filthy, stinking mess' as toilets spill raw sewage into NSW homes

image.altText: A woman with dark hair and wearing a hat sits in an aeroplane.

props.synopsis: From an alleged poisoning plot to uprooted royals on the run and a secret romance that divided a family, these are just a few accounts of Australia's royal encounters.

title.children: Before the rise of Queen Mary, another Sydney girl spent her life as a wandering queen in exile
